elements.content: A functional indium-organic framework with an anionic skeleton, [(CH3)2NH2]­[In­(BDCPPI)]·0.5DMF·H2O (compound 1, H4BDCPPI = N,N′-bis­(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)­pyromellitic diimide, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), has been solvothermally synthesized. Compound 1 with a (4, 4)-connected pts network is constructed by negative [In­(OOC)4]− secondary building units (SBUs) and expanded tetracarboxylate ligands with functional imide groups. Meanwhile, the overall framework possesses large open channels of 17.3 × 5.5 Å with a high solvent-accessible volume that occupied about 69.2% of the total cell volume. Due to its anionic skeleton and imide-functional channels, compound 1 can efficiently adsorb large-sized carcinogenic Basic Red 9 (BR9) and Basic Violet 14 (BV14) under the synergetic promotion of Coulombic interaction, hydrogen bonding, and ion exchange and can display a repelling effect to anionic dyes. In addition, the maximum adsorption capacities for BR9 and BV14 are as high as 245 and 227 mg g–1, respectively. With regard to series of mixtures with oppositely charged dyes, compound 1 can selectively trap carcinogenic dyes. Therefore, compound 1 should be a promising metal–organic framework (MOF)-based material for the efficient and selective adsorption of carcinogenic dyes.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Due to their predesigned architectures, functional surface areas, tunable pore metrics, variable topologies, and high porosity, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as a new class of porous hybrid materials, have recently received abundant interest for the diverse applications in gas storage and separation, contaminant detection and removal, catalysis, luminescence, etc.

elements.content: Organic dyes, as a kind of vital colorants, are increasingly utilized in plenty of industrial fields, such as paper, textiles, plastic, leather, cosmetics, and food processing. However, they are also hard to oxidize and degrade, which may seriously aggravate the discharge of wastewater and trigger lots of serious environmental concerns. Notably, based on the standard of European textile ecology, nine dyes, such as Basic Red 9 (BR9) and Basic Violet 14 (BV14), have been classified as carcinogens. Additionally, the large size of carcinogenic BR9 and BV14 makes them more difficult to be removed, which also requires larger window sizes for the materials used in subsequent processing. Integrating all the above into account, there is an urgent need to create new materials for removing carcinogenic dyes from effluent. Several techniques have been developed to meet this challenge, including photodegradation, biological decolorization, adsorption and membrane processes. Among these techniques, adsorption is way ahead due to its high efficiency, economic feasibility, straightforward operation, and environmental protection. Numerous adsorbents have been explored to remove dyes, such as activated carbon, zeolites, two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials, and MOFs. Compared to conventional adsorbents with poor adsorption capacity and low selectivity, MOFs can be regarded as outstanding candidates for highly efficient elimination of dye pollutions. MOFs materials display a high adsorption amount, rapid capture rate, and efficient separation for charged dye molecules, thanks to the designable electrical property, adjustable window size, and modifiable channel surface. The theoretical reasons are expounded as follow: (a) On the basis of the reaction mechanisms of ion-exchange and Coulombic interactions, ionic MOFs materials can rapidly adsorb dyes that possess opposite charges to the MOFs but exclude dyes with the same charges. Thus, the adsorption and separation of differently charged dyes is achieved. (b) By taking advantage of the tunable pore sizes of MOFs, the window sizes of the adsorbents can be designed in advance to match the sizes of target dyes. (c) By utilizing the strategy of ligand functionalization, the channels of MOFs can be decorated with predesigned functional groups, which could enhance the host–guest interaction and promote dyes absorption. Testified by above aspects, ionic-functional MOF materials possess more invincible superiorities in the efficient and selective adsorption of large-sized carcinogenic dyes. Therefore, the reasonable predesign and precise synthesis of MOF materials for addressing carcinogenic dye contaminations has become the key to environmental governance.

elements.content: Inspired by the positive charge and abundant existence of amino groups of carcinogenic BR9 and BV14, we expected to develop a new MOF to facilitate the adsorption of BR9 and BV14 by creating more host–guest interactions. In an attempt to accomplish the above-mentioned desires, negative inorganic nodes and elongated and functional organic backbones are introduced simultaneously. From a metal perspective, indium, as a high cycle p-block metal, has attracted widespread concern for its tendency to form charged building units, such as negatively charged [In­(OOC)4]− monomers, positively charged [In3O­(OOC)6]+ trimers, and [In2(OH)] dimers. Even the coexistence of these building units can create more skeletons with different electrical properties. These charged secondary building units (SBUs) are generally formed by the coordination of carboxylic acids with indium. Besides that, open channels with appropriate window sizes are also crucial for large-sized dyes adsorption. An expanded tetracarboxylate ligand N,N′-bis­(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)­pyromellitic diimide (H4BDCPPI) functionalized with imide groups has been selected to synthesize a prospective In-MOF with pts topology, named [(CH3)2NH2]­[In­(BDCPPI)]·0.5DMF·H2O (compound 1). Fortunately, the 3D skeleton of compound 1 is anionic, which brings about the Coulombic interaction and ion-exchange during the adsorption of cationic organics. Moreover, the imide groups decorated within the framework can form hydrogen bonds with the amino groups of the carcinogenic dyes, further impulsing the adsorption through the host–guest interaction. It is worth noting that, compound 1 also features a large pore window about 17.3 × 5.5 Å and exhibits high porosity (69.2%), which are higher than those of other In-based MOFs with the same topology. Expectantly, compound 1 presents commendable performances in the efficient and selective adsorption of carcinogenic BR9 and BV14 through multiple host–guest interactions. The maximum adsorption capacities for BR9 and BV14 are high, up to 245 and 227 mg g–1, respectively. Additionally, compound 1 can also rapidly capture other cationic dyes with various sizes and shapes. In summary, compound 1 can be used as a prominent adsorbent for the highly selective and efficient adsorption of carcinogenic dyes.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were obtained from a chemical company and used without additional purification. The infrared (IR) spectra were measured on a Bruker IFS-66v/S FTIR spectrometer. The elemental data of C, H, and N were tested on a Vario MICRO elemental analyzer. The patterns of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) were achieved on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). UV-vis adsorption spectra of dyes were performed on a SHIMADZU UV-2450 UV-visible spectrophotometer by applying an ethanol solution as the blank control. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were recorded on TGA Q500 thermogravimetric analyzer with the temperature range from 30 to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1 in air.

Light yellow octahedron single crystals were collected and dried in air (yield 76%, based on In­(NO3)3·4H2O). Elemental analysis (wt %) calcd for compound 1: C, 46.88; H, 2.87; N, 6.49. elements.content: To investigate the effects of the anionic skeleton on the adsorption and separation of organic dyes, seven typical dyes with multifarious charges and configurations were selected, including electrically positive BR9, BV14, Rhodamine B (RhB), Methylene Blue (MLB), and negatively charged Orange II, Methyl Orange (MO), and Neutral Red (NR) as neutral components. All the dye-adsorbed measurements were tested by immersing freshly synthesized compound 1 (10 mg) in the dye-contaminated ethanol solutions at room temperature with consecutively magnetic stirring in dark conditions. To initiate the adsorption rate tests, the obtained compound 1 (10 mg) was immersed into 15 mL of 10 ppm prepared different dye solutions. At different predetermined time intervals, the unadsorbed dyes concentrations were recorded by monitoring the intensities of the maximum absorption peaks via UV–vis absorbance spectra. The maximum adsorption amounts for different cationic and neutral dyes were measured in 50 mL dye solutions with different initial concentrations, which were mixed well with magnetic stirring for 24 h. By means of a similar process to that of the rate measurement, 16 mL two-component systems of BR9 & MO and BV14 & MO with an 1:1 original concentration ratio (10:10 ppm) were chosen to verify the selective adsorption of compound 1. The absorption amounts of dyes at sampling time Q t and at equilibrium Q e were calculated as follows: Q t = ( C 0 − C t ) V / m Q e = ( C 0 − C e ) V / m in which C 0, C t , and C e are the concentrations of dyes at initial, sampling time, and equilibrium, respectively. V represents the volume of the dye solutions and m represents the mass of the adsorbents. Maximum adsorption isotherms were fitted using Langmuir and Freundlich models.
elements.clean_text:
Dye Adsorption and Separation Measurements

To investigate the effects of the anionic skeleton on the adsorption and separation of organic dyes, seven typical dyes with multifarious charges and configurations were selected, including electrically positive BR9, BV14, Rhodamine B (RhB), Methylene Blue (MLB), and negatively charged Orange II, Methyl Orange (MO), and Neutral Red (NR) as neutral components. All the dye-adsorbed measurements were tested by immersing freshly synthesized compound 1 (10 mg) in the dye-contaminated ethanol solutions at room temperature with consecutively magnetic stirring in dark conditions. To initiate the adsorption rate tests, the obtained compound 1 (10 mg) was immersed into 15 mL of 10 ppm prepared different dye solutions. At different predetermined time intervals, the unadsorbed dyes concentrations were recorded by monitoring the intensities of the maximum absorption peaks via UV-vis absorbance spectra. The maximum adsorption amounts for different cationic and neutral dyes were measured in 50 mL dye solutions with different initial concentrations, which were mixed well with magnetic stirring for 24 h. By means of a similar process to that of the rate measurement, 16 mL two-component systems of BR9 & MO and BV14 & MO with an 1:1 original concentration ratio (10:10 ppm) were chosen to verify the selective adsorption of compound 1. The absorption amounts of dyes at sampling time  Q t  and at equilibrium Q  e  were calculated as follows: 1       Q   t   =  (   C   0   -   C   t   )  V / m      2       Q   e   =  (   C   0   -   C   e   )  V / m    in which C 0, C  t , and C  e  are the concentrations of dyes at initial, sampling time, and equilibrium, respectively. V represents the volume of the dye solutions and m represents the mass of the adsorbents. Maximum adsorption isotherms were fitted using Langmuir and Freundlich models.

elements.content: Compound 1 was recorded on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at 293 K to acquire the crystallographic data. The structure of compound 1 was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares with SHELXL-2016. All the indium, C, N, and O atoms of the compound were located first and refined with the anisotropical technology. The hydrogen atoms of the ligand were placed geometrically. According to the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data, TGA, and C, H, and N elemental analyses, the eventual composition of compound 1 was inferred. The void volume of the compound was calculated by PLATON/SQUEEZE, and the related topology information was calculated using TOPOS software. The detailed crystal data and characteristic bond lengths and angles for compound 1 are summarized in Tables S1 and S2, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Compound 1 was recorded on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at 293 K to acquire the crystallographic data. The structure of compound 1 was solved by direct methods and refined on F  2  by full-matrix least-squares with SHELXL-2016. All the indium, C, N, and O atoms of the compound were located first and refined with the anisotropical technology. The hydrogen atoms of the ligand were placed geometrically. According to the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data, TGA, and C, H, and N elemental analyses, the eventual composition of compound 1 was inferred. The void volume of the compound was calculated by PLATON/SQUEEZE, and the related topology information was calculated using TOPOS software. The detailed crystal data and characteristic bond lengths and angles for compound 1 are summarized in Tables S1 and S2, respectively.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in a tetragonal crystal system with the space group of P42/mmc. As depicted in a,b, the framework is composed of a mononuclear indium inorganic SBU and an organic SBU functionalized with imide groups. Each indium ion is chelated to four bidentate carboxylic acid groups derived from four ligands, which can be defined as a 4-connected node with tetrahedral geometry. Each ligand binds to four independent metal centers, resulting in the formation of a rectangle geometry. The alternant assembly of these SBUs results in a (4, 4)-connected pts network with the point symbol of (42 · 84) (c, d and Figure S4). As shown in e and Figure S3, there exists two types of channels with approximate diameters of 17.3 × 5.5 and 15.1 × 8.2 Å along the (100) and (010) directions (excluding the van der Waals radius), respectively. Calculated by the PLATON software, the total solvent accessible volume of compound 1 is 3401.2 Å3 per unit cell, which makes up approximately 69.2% of the cell volume. As rendered in a, the square channels with a window size of 8.2 × 8.2 Å are sufficiently modified by imide groups along the (001) direction (Figure S3). From the perspective of the (010) direction (b), the imide groups anchor on window edges of the large channel with 17.3 × 5.5 Å, which can form the hydrogen bonds with carcinogenic dyes and serve as active sites during the adsorption process. Noteworthily, the charged behavior of the skeleton and the countercation (CH3)2NH2 + located within the channels are vital for the capture of cationic dyes. The counterions resulted from the decomposition of DMF solvent are applied to balance the charge of the anionic skeleton. The large open channels, decorated imide groups, and charged characteristic of compound 1 make the highly efficient and rapid adsorption of carcinogenic dyes possible.

Results and Discussion

Structure Description

Single-crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in a tetragonal crystal system with the space group of P42/mmc. As depicted in a,b, the framework is composed of a mononuclear indium inorganic SBU and an organic SBU functionalized with imide groups. Each indium ion is chelated to four bidentate carboxylic acid groups derived from four ligands, which can be defined as a 4-connected node with tetrahedral geometry. Each ligand binds to four independent metal centers, resulting in the formation of a rectangle geometry. The alternant assembly of these SBUs results in a (4, 4)-connected pts network with the point symbol of (42 ⋅ 84) (c, d and Figure S4). As shown in e and Figure S3, there exists two types of channels with approximate diameters of 17.3 × 5.5 and 15.1 × 8.2 Å along the (100) and (010) directions (excluding the van der Waals radius), respectively. Calculated by the PLATON software, the total solvent accessible volume of compound 1 is 3401.2 Å3 per unit cell, which makes up approximately 69.2% of the cell volume. As rendered in a, the square channels with a window size of 8.2 × 8.2 Å are sufficiently modified by imide groups along the (001) direction (Figure S3). From the perspective of the (010) direction (b), the imide groups anchor on window edges of the large channel with 17.3 × 5.5 Å, which can form the hydrogen bonds with carcinogenic dyes and serve as active sites during the adsorption process. Noteworthily, the charged behavior of the skeleton and the countercation (CH3)2NH2 + located within the channels are vital for the capture of cationic dyes. The counterions resulted from the decomposition of DMF solvent are applied to balance the charge of the anionic skeleton. The large open channels, decorated imide groups, and charged characteristic of compound 1 make the highly efficient and rapid adsorption of carcinogenic dyes possible.

elements.content: Similar variation trends also occurred in the adsorption processes of RhB, MLB, and NR (Figure S6). The first-order derivative of adsorption amounts with time, a critical indicatrix to evaluate adsorption efficiency, discloses the initial adsorption rates of compound 1. Delightedly, the adsorption rates of BR9, BV14, RhB, MLB, and NR have been valued as high as 7.3, 6.7, 3.0, 14.6, and 13.2 mg g–1 min–1, respectively (). With the sizes of the cationic dyes increasing, the adsorption rates decline. These results show that compound 1 is able to rapidly adsorb BR9 and BV14. For further comparison, the intensity of the characteristic adsorption peaks remained almost unchanged for MO and Orange II, which shows that the anionic dyes do not get access to the framework, even if their sizes match the window size of the framework, due to the charge repulsion (Figure S7). PXRD patterns of samples after adsorption agreed well with that of the as-synthesized crystals, ruling out the possibility of the adsorption caused by the collapse of the skeleton during adsorption progress (Figure S1b).

elements.content: The adsorption capability, as an important index of any adsorbent from the perspective of industrial wastewater purification, is affected by the initial concentration of dye solutions. Thus, the adsorption isotherm was measured to evaluate the maximum adsorption capacity by varying the original concentration. Langmuir and Freundlich models are applied to fit the maximum adsorption curves, and it was found that the Langmuir model is more suitable for the calculation of adsorption data (Figure S9). Impressively, the adsorbent displays the maximum adsorption capacities for BR9 and BV14, as high as up to 245 and 227 mg g–1, respectively (). As far as we know, very few MOFs are applied to capture BR9 and BV14, and the trapping capacity of the compound 1 outperforms many reported materials, such as Al-MCM-41 and Ca-bentonite (see Tables S4 and S5). The surprising adsorption amounts for these carcinogenic dyes may be ascribed to the following aspects: (a) The suitable pore size and high porosity provide opportunities for the adsorption of large-sized dye molecules. (b) On account of the host–guest interactions of Coulombic interaction and ion-exchange, anionic compound 1 can rapidly trap cationic dyes. (c) The imide groups decorated on the surface of the pore can form hydrogen bonds with the amino groups of carcinogenic dyes to strengthen the host–guest interaction and facilitate the adsorption of the carcinogenic dyes. FT-IR studies were employed to test carcinogenic dyes, compound 1, and dye-adsorbed samples. The analogous structure and functional groups of BR9 and BV14 caused their FT-IR spectra to be similar. Therefore, BR9 was selected as a representative to discuss the mechanism in detail. As shown in Figure S8a, the amino peaks at 3173 and 3312 cm–1 were discovered for BR9, which blue-shifted toward higher wavenumbers of 3218 and 3348 cm–1 for compound 1 after adsorption. Meanwhile, the red shift is observed from 1668 to 1655 cm–1 for CO stretching vibration of compound 1 before and after adsorption. These shifts clearly explained the formation of hydrogen bonds between amino functional groups of BR9 and BV14 and the imide groups of compound 1.

Although the adsorption capacity of RhB (84 mg g–1) is much lower than those of other cationic dyes, it is still superior to other materials such as Li-UPC-5. Conclusion

A functional indium-organic framework with an anionic skeleton, [(CH3)2NH2]­[In­(BDCPPI)]·0.5DMF·H2O (compound 1, H4BDCPPI = N,N′-bis­(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)­pyromellitic diimide, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), has been solvothermally synthesized. Compound 1 with a (4, 4)-connected pts network is constructed by negative [In­(OOC)4]− secondary building units (SBUs) and expanded tetracarboxylate ligands with functional imide groups. Meanwhile, the overall framework possesses large open channels of 17.3 × 5.5 Å with a high solvent-accessible volume that occupied about 69.2% of the total cell volume. Due to its anionic skeleton and imide-functional channels, compound 1 can efficiently adsorb large-sized carcinogenic Basic Red 9 (BR9) and Basic Violet 14 (BV14) under the synergetic promotion of Coulombic interaction, hydrogen bonding, and ion exchange and can display a repelling effect to anionic dyes. In addition, the maximum adsorption capacities for BR9 and BV14 are as high as 245 and 227 mg g–1, respectively. With regard to series of mixtures with oppositely charged dyes, compound 1 can selectively trap carcinogenic dyes. Therefore, compound 1 should be a promising metal–organic framework (MOF)-based material for the efficient and selective adsorption of carcinogenic dyes.

Inspired by the positive charge and abundant existence of amino groups of carcinogenic BR9 and BV14, we expected to develop a new MOF to facilitate the adsorption of BR9 and BV14 by creating more host–guest interactions. In an attempt to accomplish the above-mentioned desires, negative inorganic nodes and elongated and functional organic backbones are introduced simultaneously. From a metal perspective, indium, as a high cycle p-block metal, has attracted widespread concern for its tendency to form charged building units, such as negatively charged [In­(OOC)4]− monomers, positively charged [In3O­(OOC)6]+ trimers, and [In2(OH)] dimers. Even the coexistence of these building units can create more skeletons with different electrical properties. These charged secondary building units (SBUs) are generally formed by the coordination of carboxylic acids with indium. Besides that, open channels with appropriate window sizes are also crucial for large-sized dyes adsorption. An expanded tetracarboxylate ligand N,N′-bis­(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)­pyromellitic diimide (H4BDCPPI) functionalized with imide groups has been selected to synthesize a prospective In-MOF with pts topology, named [(CH3)2NH2]­[In­(BDCPPI)]·0.5DMF·H2O (compound 1). Fortunately, the 3D skeleton of compound 1 is anionic, which brings about the Coulombic interaction and ion-exchange during the adsorption of cationic organics. Moreover, the imide groups decorated within the framework can form hydrogen bonds with the amino groups of the carcinogenic dyes, further impulsing the adsorption through the host–guest interaction. It is worth noting that, compound 1 also features a large pore window about 17.3 × 5.5 Å and exhibits high porosity (69.2%), which are higher than those of other In-based MOFs with the same topology. Expectantly, compound 1 presents commendable performances in the efficient and selective adsorption of carcinogenic BR9 and BV14 through multiple host–guest interactions. The maximum adsorption capacities for BR9 and BV14 are high, up to 245 and 227 mg g–1, respectively. Additionally, compound 1 can also rapidly capture other cationic dyes with various sizes and shapes. In summary, compound 1 can be used as a prominent adsorbent for the highly selective and efficient adsorption of carcinogenic dyes.

Results and DiscussionStructure Description

Single-crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in a tetragonal crystal system with the space group of P42/mmc. As depicted in a,b, the framework is composed of a mononuclear indium inorganic SBU and an organic SBU functionalized with imide groups. Each indium ion is chelated to four bidentate carboxylic acid groups derived from four ligands, which can be defined as a 4-connected node with tetrahedral geometry. Each ligand binds to four independent metal centers, resulting in the formation of a rectangle geometry. The alternant assembly of these SBUs results in a (4, 4)-connected pts network with the point symbol of (42 · 84) (c, d and Figure S4). As shown in e and Figure S3, there exists two types of channels with approximate diameters of 17.3 × 5.5 and 15.1 × 8.2 Å along the (100) and (010) directions (excluding the van der Waals radius), respectively. Calculated by the PLATON software, the total solvent accessible volume of compound 1 is 3401.2 Å3 per unit cell, which makes up approximately 69.2% of the cell volume. As rendered in a, the square channels with a window size of 8.2 × 8.2 Å are sufficiently modified by imide groups along the (001) direction (Figure S3). From the perspective of the (010) direction (b), the imide groups anchor on window edges of the large channel with 17.3 × 5.5 Å, which can form the hydrogen bonds with carcinogenic dyes and serve as active sites during the adsorption process. Noteworthily, the charged behavior of the skeleton and the countercation (CH3)2NH2 + located within the channels are vital for the capture of cationic dyes. (b) On account of the host–guest interactions of Coulombic interaction and ion-exchange, anionic compound 1 can rapidly trap cationic dyes. (c) The imide groups decorated on the surface of the pore can form hydrogen bonds with the amino groups of carcinogenic dyes to strengthen the host–guest interaction and facilitate the adsorption of the carcinogenic dyes. FT-IR studies were employed to test carcinogenic dyes, compound 1, and dye-adsorbed samples. The analogous structure and functional groups of BR9 and BV14 caused their FT-IR spectra to be similar. Therefore, BR9 was selected as a representative to discuss the mechanism in detail. As shown in Figure S8a, the amino peaks at 3173 and 3312 cm–1 were discovered for BR9, which blue-shifted toward higher wavenumbers of 3218 and 3348 cm–1 for compound 1 after adsorption. Meanwhile, the red shift is observed from 1668 to 1655 cm–1 for CO stretching vibration of compound 1 before and after adsorption. These shifts clearly explained the formation of hydrogen bonds between amino functional groups of BR9 and BV14 and the imide groups of compound 1.
